chapter.title: What is &PRODNAME;?
chapter.para: &PRODNAME; is an open-source backend server that sends out XML feeds to internal teams. Essentially, it accepts data and sends data back out when requested. The idea is that there will be many of these throughout the company.
The purpose of &PRODNAME; is to serve Atom feeds as well as to be a repository for those feeds.

You can install &PRODNAME; on any server that meets the minimal configuration requirements:
Operating System: Linux Centos 6+, Ubuntu 10+, Apple Mac OS X
Java Virtual Machine: Oracle Java v1.6 or OpenJDK 1.6

note.para: See for a list of documentation about these components.

chapter.title: How Does &PRODNAME; Work?
chapter.para: &PRODNAME; is an AtomPub server based upon the Apache Abdera project. It functions as a framework for accessing, processing, aggregating, and indexing Atom-formatted events.

&PRODNAME; was designed to make it easy to build both generalized and specialized persistence mechanisms for Atom XML data, based on the Atom Syndication Format and the Atom Publishing Protocol. Atom is an IETF-ratified event syndication format that may have multiple representations. It is widely used, with many libraries written for it. You can read more about the Atom Syndication Format and the Atom Publishing Protocol in the references suggested at .
&PRODNAME; can use several relational databases, including H2, PostgreSQL, Microsoft SQL Server, and HSQLDB.
&PRODNAME; fully supports &POST; (creating new Atom entries) and &GET; (retrieving a feed or a single Atom entry); it has stubs to support &DELETE; and &PUT; if needed.

figure.title: &PRODNAME; collects published events and forwards them to subscribers.

chapter.para:
As illustrated above, &PRODNAME; can do more than simply listen for published events. It can provide subscribers with personalized feeds of only the events most relevant to them. For example:
Failures can be routed to an on-call's mobile phone.
Warnings requiring proactive investigation can be routed to an on-site technician's tablet.
Normal progress messages can be routed to an administrator's console.
Records of successful task completion can be fed to a program for analysis and reporting.

section.title: Using &PRODNAME;
section.para: An Atom feed consists of one or more entries. You can get a feed from &PRODNAME;, select entries from within a feed, add entries to a feed, and add categories to a feed entry.
You can also use &PRODNAME; to tell you what version of &PRODNAME; you are using, if &PRODNAME; is deployed in a manner supporting that functionality.

section.title: Getting a Feed
section.para: Your &PRODNAME; may be configured to collect a large number of Atom feeds, creating a database containing much more information than you wish to process at a given time. To retrieve a specific feed or selected entries within a feed from &PRODNAME;'s database, issue an HTTP &GET;. You can use &GET; to ask for a specific entry, move forward and backward within the feed, search the feed for entries in specific categories, and translate entries to JSON.
To get the feed from your &PRODNAME;'s database, perform a &GET; against its URL. In a default installation, that URL is shaped like http://localhost:8080/namespace/feed/.
The response to your &GET; will include a feed head with several links to entries within the feed.

example.title: Feed head with links to "last", "current", and "next" relative positions

section.para: The feed head provides links to the oldest entry within the feed, the entry currently being viewed, and, if they are available, links to the next and previous pages of entries.

listitem.para: rel="last" identifies a link to the oldest Atom entry in the database for this feed. This entry is "last" in that all newer entries have been added ahead of it, but it was the first entry added to the feed.
rel="current" identifies a link to the currently-selected Atom entry.

rel="next" identifies a link to the next page of Atom entries, containing entries newer than the entry marked as rel="current". A query with the direction=forward parameter moves in the same direction as this next page.

section.para: The feed head may also include a link to the previous page of Atom entries, identified as rel="previous". A query with the direction=backward parameter moves in the same direction as this previous page.

In the Atom feed, each entry includes a self-referencing link, marked as rel="self". The self-referencing link is constructed to use HTTP or HTTPS, depending upon whether you use HTTP &POST; or HTTPS &POST;.

listitem.para: If you use HTTP &POST;, the self-referencing link resembles >https://domain.com/namespace/feed/entries/urn:uuid:9b850562-d357-4cf8-8811-048a6730e869" rel="self" />..
If you use HTTPS &POST;, the self-referencing link resembles >link href="http://domain.com/namespace/feed/entries/urn:uuid:9b850562-d357-4cf8-8811-048a6730e869" rel="self" />..

section.title: Adding Entries to a Feed
section.para: You can add an entry to a feed in Atom Hopper's database. To do this, issue an HTTP &POST; to &PRODNAME;'s endpoint, with an HTTP Content-Type header set to application/atom+xml.

tip.para: Use whatever tool you prefer to issue a &POST; to &PRODNAME;.
You can use HTTP &POST; or HTTPS &POST;. To support HTTPS/SSL, you may need to make changes to Apache Tomcat or whatever application server you use.

section.para: If your &POST; to the &PRODNAME; endpoint successfully added an entry, you'll receive an HTTP 201 (created) response and the Atom XML you posted will be echoed back to you in the response body.
The following is an example of a simple Atom entry. In addition to delivering its content, it describes its own title, creation date, author, and three category labels.

The structure of a complex Atom entry is similar to that of a simple Atom entry, expanded to convey additional descriptive information such as contact information for multiple authors and contributors, copyright information, and a summary of the content.

section.title: Adding Categories to a Feed Entry
section.para: &PRODNAME; can query a feed for entries matching specified categories.
&PRODNAME; can also assign a category or several categories to an entry, so that the entry can later be retrieved along with all entries in the same category.

To add categories to an Atom entry, include the category element with a term attribute. Do this once for every category you wish to add to the entry. For example,
To label an entry as belonging to the "servers" category, specify <category term="servers" />
To label an entry as belonging to three categories — "servers", "failures", and "mission-critical" — specify <category term="servers" /> and <category term="failures" /> and <category term="mission-critical" />

By adding multiple category labels to a feed entry, you make it possible to retrieve that entry in multiple ways and use it for narrowly-targeted purposes. An entry categorized as "servers", "failures", and "mission-critical" can be retrieved by a query seeking all entries relating to servers, or all entries related to failures of any kind, or all entries related to mission-critical devices. It can also be retrieved by a query seeking a very specific combination of categories, representing only failures for mission-critical servers.

section.title: Selecting Entries from a Feed
section.para: You can use &PRODNAME; to examine an Atom feed and select entries that meet your criteria. To do that, issue a query with parameters describing the content you are seeking.

Starting from the current marker or entry, the direction in which to traverse the feed to collect more entries.
The number of entries returned. If the value specified is greater than the actual number of entries, the actual number of entries will be used.

section.title: Getting &PRODNAME; Version Information

important.para: This functionality is available only if &PRODNAME; is deployed via a WAR file. You can accomplish this by either the recommended deployment method or the RPM method, which also installs a WAR.

section.para: To find out what version of &PRODNAME; you are running, you can perform an HTTP &GET; with /buildinfo appended to the URL where &PRODNAME; is mapped.

section.title: Translating a Feed to JSON (Experimental)
section.para: By default, Atom feeds are formatted as XML. You can ask for a feed to be formatted as JSON by appending format=json to its URL, as in http://localhost:8080/namespace/feed/?format=json.
&PRODNAME; uses the Abdera JSON Writer to translate simple Atom feed entries to JSON.

important.para: Be sure to fully test the translation of your Atom entries to confirm that the JSON translation matches the XML original.
If you want to embed some JSON into an Atom XML entry, wrap the JSON content in an XML CDATA section.

section.title: Scaling &PRODNAME;: Multiple Feeds and Multiple Databases
section.para:
You can configure &PRODNAME; to use multiple databases per feed, using the default data adapter. For example, you can define a scenario such as the following, where three unique feeds each map to a different database server:
http://localhost/myfeed/events/ maps to PostgreSQL Server 1
http://localhost/something/alerts/ maps to MySQL Server 1
http://localhost/hello/world/ maps to PostgreSQL Server 2

Since &PRODNAME;'s default adapter uses Hibernate, you can achieve this three-way mapping by modifying two configuration files.
atom-server.cfg.xml configures a single feed or multiple feeds
application-context.xml configures connection to a single database or multiple databases
To establish the three-way mapping described above, create configuration files as shown below.
In atom-server.cfg.xml, define three unique feeds. Use feed-source and publisher to map each feed to the proper database.
In atom-server.cfg.xml, define databases to receive the three feeds. This example defines two PostgreSQL databases and one MySQL database.

important.para: To use multiple databases, make sure your application server includes the JDBC drivers in its classpath. If your application server is Apache Tomcat, you can put the JDBC drivers in the lib folder.
